channel.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
channel.description:
We have all heard about how editing the client automatically flags your account, because the server makes a check with the client.
My question is exactly how does this work? And where is the file in the client which contains it?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Back when I worked with deobs, I alwasy just edited getUID() to return math.random() and not save anything, giving you a unique UID on every run. That really isn’t a very good way to do things though, ideally you should keep the same UID for each account you run.

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @fernando400 fernando400
item.description:
@fernando400 wrote:

Cant i just delete it? and then i use the deob, and when i wanna play with my main i delete again and play with it ?

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

I think they are really using the UID to relate accounts. I got one of my mains banned because of that. I had never broken a rule with him, and the rule I was breaking with the other acc was not autoing.

Note: If you want to be able to play with the deob without having to worry about getting legit accs banned, you can modify the deob to use a different path or file. Search for “file_store” or “uid.dat” and you will find the code that deals with it.

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

frank_:

do as i did not, disregard all claims of detectability, for it just puts you off.

I’ll agree with that.

If you don’t care about losing a few accounts, then really the best way to learn is to take what people have said and try it. It would be unwise to just take a cheating community’s word on anything. Find out for yourself taking the things they have said with a grain of salt. It really is the best way to internalize anything concerning the client and how it works.

One thing I would really suggest though is save your current uid and store it someplace safe (for non-hacking moments). Also, I would lightly suggest learning how to use socks proxies.

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

nah, the servers says something more along the lines of

i would like to see some information about field/method X of class Y

they must know what the name of the field/method and class names are, on that note, its possible that they can call methods such as getMethods, but they cannot [afaik] reuse that result to count the number of methods

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

Thanks for the replies. Once I get popcorn’s deobfuscator working I will have a better look.

I knew about the reflection system, but I’m still not sure on how it works. Does the server just say something like “Hey what are your classes named” and the client replies with “err… class 1,2 etc”?

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

We know several hard facts about detection, but a lot of what people talk about is just speculation.

Facts:

  • Jagex has the ability, via reflection, to check method/field names and access flags, to invoke methods and send their return values to the server, and to get and set the values of fields. However, they don’t necessarily do all or any of these at a given time.

  • Jagex has placed, in many methods, variables which are referred to as method counters.
    The code looks something like this:

private static int errechnenScheisse() {
  counterAB34++;
  ....
}

In theory, they could use the above mentioned reflection methods to grab the value of a counter and compare it. I haven’t thought about it in a long time, to be perfectly honest - someone who’s more up to date with the client should start logging reflection actions so we know what they actually do.

  • When the client is run as an application (or any time that the game’s own frame isn’t null), the client sends a unique number to the server (like an error code).

  • When a certain byte in the login packet equals one (which it always does now), the client maintains and transmits a log of your last 40 (or something near) mouse clicks in a hash that also contains position delta and timing information. This is not the only information about your game state that the server harvests. In case of an extensive investigation, a Jagex employee could perfectly recreate what you see while playing the game (so humanlike mouse behaviour is important).

Most people’s deobfuscation processes or sloppy edits interfere with the client in some way that is detectable to the above methods. However, there are some things that people only think might contribute to being banned.

Conjectures:

  • Sharing a UID, IP address/hostname, or client instance with a ‘dirty’ account might cause your ‘clean’ accounts to come under scrutiny. The UID-purge in particular is an item of faith among SCAR users.

  • It has been suggested that Jagex has implemented unique identifiers on all items, so that the flow of duped and macroed items/gold can be easily traced and the characters involved with it banned. The common solution to this fear seems to be transfers through multiple characters. Personally, I would consider REAL laundering via market sites.

  • Some people think that Jagex checks whether or not you’ve loaded the game via the RuneScape website by comparing your game IP to recent web logs (or something similar). This is entirely possible- but, as with other guesses about what Jagex does serverside, there’s no proof one way or the other.

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

long story short, if you rename any of their methods or fields, the ban hammer may hit you.

do as i did not, disregard all claims of detectability, for it just puts you off.

rather than hack up their methods of detection, just stop your methods being discovered, be it by redefining the class, modifying the reflection to throw a relevant error, or pre-/post-fixing your fields with a varying [, preferably non-ascii,] character.

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

Well, you can always reverse everything Jagex implements in the client to “check”. You can always inject custom CRC values etc for the data file checks.

Is it not better to avoid the path they seem to be going down, though?

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

this person has a good point Hex, this is a good question which we would also like to know,

well a few things i know is that they pickup method modifiers, and if edited you == flag

they can also tell if you launch the applet as an application, and you == flag

i know a few others, but they are the more ‘Obvious’ Ones.

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

item.title: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?
item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

Ignore him, for he is a douchebag.

There are a few things. First and foremost, we have reflection checks.
Search for “java.lang.reflect” among the client classes, and you will come up with some methods that invoke methods, get information about classes/methods/fields, and can send this information to the server. So what ends up happening is, if the client is edited/refactored &c, the server might know about it, depending on how Jagex implements these checks.

We have all heard about how editing the client automatically flags your account
... untrue. There are dozens of edits you can do that go beneath the radar on Jagex's part. They _cannot_ CRC their own classes, apart from checking their .dat cache files, and those checks are done in the loader, not the true client.

There are of course things like method counters and execution timers, but these are only relevant if you severely edit the code.

The extent of the edits, and whether Jagex have sufficient API or resources to check them decide whether you will be found out or not.

Read full topic
item.source: What is in the client that makes editing so detectable?

Do YOU know?
